title: Replace (command)
text:
In <a href="computing">computing</a>, codice_1 is a <a href="command%20%28computing%29">command</a> that is used to replace one or more existing <a href="computer%20file">computer file</a>s or add new files to a target <a href="directory%20%28computing%29">directory</a>. Files with a <a href="hidden%20file">hidden</a> or <a href="system%20file">system</a> <a href="file%20attribute">attribute</a> set cannot be replaced using codice_1. The command lists all files that are replaced.
History.
The codice_1 command first appeared in <a href="MS-DOS">MS-DOS</a> 3.2 and has been included in most versions of MS-DOS and <a href="DOS">compatibles</a> such as <a href="FreeDOS">FreeDOS</a> and <a href="PTS-DOS">PTS-DOS</a>. <a href="DR%20DOS%206.0">DR DOS 6.0</a> includes an implementation of the command. The FreeDOS version was developed by Rene Ableidinger and is licensed under the <a href="GNU%20General%20Public%20License">GPL</a>. It is also included as a console command in <a href="IBM">IBM</a> <a href="OS/2">OS/2</a>, <a href="Microsoft">Microsoft</a> <a href="Microsoft%20Windows">Windows</a>, and <a href="ReactOS">ReactOS</a>. The ReactOS version was developed by Samuel Erdtman and is licensed under the GPL.
Example.
The following command updates the files in C:\delivery\ with the <a href=".exe">.exe</a> files in C:\source\
C:\>replace "C:\source\*.exe" C:\delivery
